author: ralexstokes
content: how do we square "7732 allows long-tail builders to enter the market as the system is relatively more permissionless than working with relays today" and "builders must have at least 32 ETH staked to participate"?

author: ralexstokes
content: you could imagine some kind of buildernet-esque system with a capital provider to the barrier to entry even further, although it does seem to point to reconsidering this design decision somewhat

author: fradamt
content: This is if you want to pretend to be self-building. However one could also just set the bid to 1 gwei, do an off-protocol payment and otherwise do everything as in protocol?

author: fradamt
content:
Imo:
1. relays can still exist and essentially be a small-builder aggregator (if nothing else), fronting capital for them
2. otherwise, anyone running a validator can be a builder, which is quite a large pool of potential participants

Though it's not great that the relay option is made worse by adding this capital requirement

author: potuz
content: You mean the builder actually signs the bid, but the "real" payment is done off-protocol? if yes, then yes, this is absolutely doable and clients that want to implement such a system are free to do that (it requires some ad-hoc way of choosing bids).

author: ralexstokes
content:
yeah, these are options but it still doesn't get to the world where it becomes much simpler for builders to join the market

perhaps we can rely on the existing capital set of validators today, although that seems to start eroding the PBS abstraction in the first place

author: soispoke
content: I think today the highest barriers to entry for being a builder comes from getting access to order flow not capital requirements. Ofc it's always better if capital requirements are lower but I don't think it would make an actual difference in the current situation, even if you had 1 ETH requirements you'd still have incredibly high barriers to entry because you need to do BD to get valuable flow and be competitive in the auction

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah the bet would be long-tail builders that may only have a block every few months but may be able to materialize some rare opportunity, and i do think a market that looks like this is healthier than one that only has a small number of builders

author: potuz
content: There is a gauge that one can put on the needed capital, perhaps 1Gwei is too little and 100ETH is too much, whatever the right number is, it is something that has a parameter that may be changed/adjusted/discussed. Being permissionless however, is something binary, and a permissioned system, in which the gatekeepers are off-protocol and trusted, is a much worse market than one that drops out some long tail builders without capital that can't find a pooling system. There are no guarantees that those same builders will ever be whitelisted anyway.
